dataset.title: Do lawns simply have a more attractive suite of species than the matrix, or do the same species become more attractive when occurring on lawns?

abstract.para: Samples were taken over a two-month period (Feb-Mar 2011) during the wet season (Oct-May in Kruger National Park and Nov-May in Serengeti National Park) to maximize plant inflorescence and seed abundance for plant identification. The wet season is also the period of most intense grazing and where soil processes such as mineralization to be at a peak. Soil and plant variables were measured to quantify differences between the grazing lawns and the surrounding vegetation matrix (lawn and matrix hereafter). Foliar variables were sampled both at the community and species levels. Community-level samples were used to quantify nutritional variables (e.g., N, P, and Na) and plant structural characteristics that influence palatability (e.g., plant height, leaf to stem ratio) assayed for a bulk (composite) sample that ignores species identity. Species-level sampling was used to investigate intraspecific variation in these variables across the lawn-matrix boundary within species that are common to both lawn and matrix. In essence I ask: do lawns simply have a more attractive suite of species than the matrix, or do the same species become more attractive when occurring on lawns?

keywordSet.keyword: SANParks, South Africa, Kruger National Park, South Africa

section.title: Data Collection
section.para: Samples were taken over a two-month period (Feb-Mar 2011) during the wet season (Oct-May in Kruger National Park and Nov-May in Serengeti National Park) to maximize plant inflorescence and seed abundance for plant identification. The wet season is also the period of most intense grazing and where soil processes such as mineralization to be at a peak. Soil and plant variables were measured to quantify differences between the grazing lawns and the surrounding vegetation matrix (lawn and matrix hereafter). Foliar variables were sampled both at the community and species levels. Community-level samples were used to quantify nutritional variables (e.g., N, P, and Na) and plant structural characteristics that influence palatability (e.g., plant height, leaf to stem ratio) assayed for a bulk (composite) sample that ignores species identity. Species-level sampling was used to investigate intraspecific variation in these variables across the lawn-matrix boundary within species that are common to both lawn and matrix. In essence I ask: do lawns simply have a more attractive suite of species than the matrix, or do the same species become more attractive when occurring on lawns?

section.title: Site Identification
section.para: Six sites were identified in each of Kruger National Park (KNP) and Serengeti National Park (SNP). KNP candidate sites were identified using a combination of satellite imagery, on-site visual surveys (e.g., grazing intensity, dung, animal tracks), and past grazing lawn delineations (N. Owen-Smith, pers. comm.). SNP sites were identified with a combination of remote sensing and landscape features, which were used to predict candidate grazing lawn sites (Anderson et al. 2010). Pairs of 50 x 20 m plots were then established inside and outside of each site, for a total of 12 plots per study system. Candidate plots that were within intensely grazed areas were designated “lawn”, while plots outside the grazing lawn boundaries were designated “matrix”. In KNP, twelve candidate plot locations (six lawn, six matrix) were identified at each site. One plot was chosen randomly from the six possible candidates for each site. In SNP, plots were chosen at random within the designated lawn sites. Each paired matrix plot was placed in a similar species swath area that was beyond the boundaries of the corresponding lawn site.

section.title: Plant Diversity and Community Composition
section.para: Each plot consisted of a 1,000-m2 (50 x 20 m) modified Whittaker plot with one 100 m2, two 10 m2 and 10 nested 1-m2 subplots. A modified Whittaker plot has two distinct advantages in measuring plant communities: (1) it utilizes a systematic approach to measuring species richness in different plant communities and (2) it balances the effects of quadrat size relative to species-area (Stohlgren 1995). In other words, Whittaker plots balance the trade-offs between large-scale low-resolution surveys that capture broad landscape trends with smaller intense high-resolution surveys.

Each plot’s long axis was aligned to capture maximum spatial and vegetative variation, if such variation was apparent to the observer. Both lawn and matrix plots were placed at a minimum of 25 m from the designated boundaries of the lawn to avoid edge effects. Species presence was noted in each of the 100-m2, 10-m2, and 1000-m2 plots. Within each of the 10 1-m2 subplots, plant species cover, richness, percent grazed grass (grass with visually identifiable grazing bite marks) and percent bare ground were recorded. Five of the 10 1-m2 subplots were designated as “intensive subplots” where additional soil and biomass samples were taken. The intensive 1-m2 subplots were selected to maximize coverage along the length and width 1000-m2 plot. Locations of the 1-m2 subplots within each lawn remained consistent within the 1,000 m2. Plant species were identified to the lowest taxonomic level.

section.title: Plant Structural and Nutritive Characteristics
section.para: Within five of the 10 intensive 1-m2 plots, standing plant biomass was destructively sampled within a 20-cm diameter ring. Bulk plant samples and leaf samples were dried (48 hours at 60 °C), weighed, and stored for later laboratory N, C, and Na analyses. Leaf-to-stem ratios (L:S) of all community-level samples were measured. L:S and specific leaf area (SLA) were also sampled at the species-level. L:S and specific leaf area (SLA) are correlated with greater nutritive quality, palatability and nutrient-use efficiency (Murray and Illius 2000).

During the species-level sampling, grass species were selected that were prevalent in both the lawn and matrix 1000-m2 plots. Three species were selected for all KNP lawns (Chloris virgata, Urochloa mosambicensis, Sporobolus nitens) and five species were selected for all SNP lawns (Eragrostis tenuifolia, Themeda triandra, Sporobolus fimbriatus, Digitaria macroblephara and Sporobolus ioclados). Three replicate samples were collected per species in lawn and matrix plots for all sites where the species occurred both in both plots. Foliar N, C, P, and Na concentrations were measured in addition to SLA and L:S. SLA samples were placed beneath a glass sheet and photographed to preserve the leaf area measurements. The photographed leaves were then transported to the US for analysis.

section.title: Soil Variables
section.para: Soil samples were taken from each of the 1-m2 intensive subplots to a depth of 10 cm. Samples were placed in separate airtight zip-lock bags and refrigerated prior to transport to the laboratory. KNP soil samples were analyzed in the Mack lab in the Biology Department at the University of Florida (Gainesville FL, USA). SNP soils were collected and air-dried following the same protocol used in KNP, and then transported to Sokoine University of Agriculture in Morogoro, Tanzania for analysis.

section.title: Laboratory Analysis
section.para: In the laboratory, leaves for SLA analysis were oven-dried (48 hours, 60°C) and weighed to the nearest ten thousandth of a gram. Leaf area was calculated using an automated image analyzer (Sigma ScanTM, Systat Software, Chicago, IL). L:S samples were separated by species and bulk samples, dried (48 hours, 60°C), weighed, and then ground for total C and N concentrations analysis on an ECS 4010 elemental analyzer (Costech Analyticla, Velencia, CA, USA). KNP plant samples were also analyzed for foliar P concentrations as an additional measure of nutrient content. Foliar P subsamples were weighed into crucibles, ashed at 500° for 6 hours in a muffle furnace and extracted with 6 M HCl. Following Murphy and Riley (1962), samples were brought to volume at 0.6 M and refrigerated between extraction and analysis with a microplate reader. After ashing, SNP foliar P was determined using the same phosphomolybdate method as KNP (Murphy and Riley 1962). Na concentration was determined using flame emission photometry (AOAC Official Method 2005).

KNP soil samples were passed through a 2-mm sieve and subsampled for gravimetric water content (dried at 105°C for 48 hours). Soils were air-dried and ground using a Spex mill (Spex Certiprep, Metuchen, NJ, USA) and analyzed for total N and C using an ECS 4010 elemental analyzer. Laboratory incubations over 21 days were used to determine mineralizable N fraction in the soils. Initial and final pools of inorganic N (NH4+ and NO3−) were extracted using 50ml of 2 M KCl. Incubated samples were moistened using 2 ml of DI water. Samples were shaken for 2 hours and left overnight before filtration and freezing prior to analysis. Inorganic N concentrations were determined calorimetrically on an Astoria-Pacific autoanalyser (Astoria-Pacific, Clackamas, OR, USA). Extractable P was used as an index of plant-available soil P as outlined in the Mehlich-1 procedure (Kuo 1996).

SNP total soil N was determined using the Kjeldahl acid-digestion method (Lang 1958). Due to the lack of refrigeration in the area, NO3- and NH4+ were not measured separately and soil results reflect total N concentrations. Total soil organic matter (SOM) was determined using loss-on-ignition method (Sollins et al. 1999). Total soil P was determined with Bray and Kurtz (pH<7.5) and Olsen bicarbonate (pH >7.5) methods. After dry ashing, foliar P was determined by the phosphomolybdate method (Watanabe and Olsen 1965).

section.title: Arbuscular Mycorrhizal Fungi Sampling and Analysis
section.para: To test the role of AMF within grazing lawns, community (SNP only) and species-level (both KNP and SNP) root samples were collected in each of the lawn and matrix plots.. Foliar P is often difficult to measure but AMF colonization rates may hint at relative amounts of plant available P in the study plots. Community root samples were taken within each of the 5 intensive 1-m2 subplots. Species-level samples were taken for each species with 3 replicates each. Whole plant samples were removed with as much fine root material and soil as possible. Upon returning to the field laboratory, roots were cleaned with water, frozen, and shipped back to the University of Missouri for laboratory analysis. Roots were then stained with the tryphan blue method (Koske and Gemma 1989) and scored (presence/absence) using the dissection microscope gridline intersection method with a minimum of 100 intersections per sample (Giovannetti 1980), i.e., each root/grid intersection was scored for the presence or absence of AMF colonization, and colonization quantified as the proportion of positive intersections out of the total number of counts.

section.title: Data Analysis
section.para: Statistical analyses were conducted in R (R Core Development Team 2011) using linear mixed models in the nlme package (Pinheiro and Bates 2000), with lawn-matrix pairs (sites) and plots within sites as nested random effects. For the species-level analysis, species and sites were treated as crossed random effects. Foliar bulk mass, L:S, SLA, N, P were prior to analysis to meet normal distributional assumptions. Mycorrhizal colonization rates (a proportion) were arcsine square-root transformed for the same reason (Sokal and Rohlf 1987). Plant community differences between the lawn and matrix were evaluated using three metrics: (1) species richness, (2) species diversity with the Shannon-Weiner diversity index, and (3) the Bray-Curtis (B-C) dissimilarity index. The B-C was computed using the R package vegan (Oksanen and Blanchet 2012). The B-C index measures the difference in community composition between pairs of sites (based on presence/absence or cover of species). Identical sites have a dissimilarity score of 0 and sites with zero species overlap have a B-C score of 1. The B-C was calculated from cumulative percent cover values (calculated across the 10 1-m2 subplots of the Whittaker plots) for all species occurring in each plot. The B-C index was computed for each lawn-matrix pair in each site, across all lawn sites, and across all matrix sites. Additionally, a bootstrap analysis (N=10,000) was conducted on the entire dataset (12 plots, regardless of lawn/site classification) to develop a null distribution of the dissimilarity index for each study system. The mean lawn vs. matrix dissimilarity was then compared with this null distribution to test the hypothesis that lawn plots were more dissimilar to matrix sites than expected by chance alone. To gauge the relative importance of species-level versus community-level patterns for lawn-matrix differences, the cover of species occurring in both lawn and matrix plots was calculated as a percentage of the total. If species-level differences occur but there is low species overlap between lawn and matrix plots, the former are less likely to be of ecological relevance than would be the case if most species occur in both lawn and matrix. This percentage of co-occurring species was computed in two ways: (1) by taking into account only species used for foliar analyses, and (2) by including all species found in both lawn and matrix plots.

attribute.attributeDefinition: Hot spot or not a hot spot
